availability.licence: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

correction.p: OCR generated transcript has not been corrected.

normalization.p: Only minor normalization where needed, if any, is indicated via markup.

punctuation.p: All punctuation marks in the source text have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.
Punctuation may be marked up with pc elements for clarification, but not exclusively.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenated words that appear at the end of a line have been retained. The hyphen, if present, is represented by the Unicode code point, and marked up with a pc element. The break="no" attribute on the lb element indicates that a single word is split across the lines.

interpretation.p: Dates, places, and names may be marked up, where useful.

body.ab:
refers to page I,
.( ) generation number.
DOZEN'S OF COUSINS.'
September 1974
How many times have you heard; "I know we're cousins, but how come?"
Well, back in 1957 I wondered the same thing, so I started investigating the
family history. Several years before, Florence McLaughlin Frost had compiled
the information but there was only one copy, and some historian along the
way had misplaced it. I started with three of our ancestors on Page 1 who
were most helpful: Kathryn McLaughlin Hendrick, Catherine Hendrick McLaughlin
and Charles Touhey. From them I received the basic outline. The rest was
obtained from many living McLaughlin's and dates on tombstones.'
I set up three duplicate notebooks, arranged so that pages can be inserted
for many generations to come. Then, we decided to have a printer make up a
booklet. This was distributed in 1958. Since then, many moons and one disastrous
flood have Come and gone. So have most of the booklets.' Since there was a great
deal of data to be added, it was suggested that a new history be written. Now,
after two years of procrastination on my part and several years of inflation
on the part of the economy a less expensive revision is herein presented.
These are Xerox copies and will be easy to duplicate at any time.
That'§ the story, but, as usual, I'd like to add a few personal comments.
First of all, the research was rev^arding, I now knew from what branch of the
family tree I had fallen. And I also knew how come the Touhey's, Keenan's et al.
were my cousins.
Secondly, it brings back a smile from my memory bank. I was being "coutted"
by James H. Regan at the time and I'm sure he felt that poking around
cemeteries---loofcing for my ancestors---was an exciting Saturday afternoon datei
Above all, though, I wish> that thik younger generation and those to
come---had been as fortunate as I was in knowing almost all the people in this
booklet. The names and dates ate here, but the warmth of their personalities
can not be put oh paper. The McLaughlin's were industrious, ;d.tty, honest,
wonderful descendhnts of Irish immigrants of the 19th century. They were--and
are-~an important part of our American heritage., I'm proud to be one of 'em!
Shirley Frost Regan

THE MCLAUGHLIN FAIUIZ
Origin of family as supplied by the Columban Fathers, Silver Creek, N.Y.
MOITO: ANCHORIS SALUTIS (The Anchor of Salvation)
The Gaelic family name is liacLocglain. It has "been anglicized McLaughlin,
MacLoughlin, Loughran, Loughlin and sometimes even Loftus.
The McLaughlin family is desended from[Mlesius,_ King of Spain, through
the Jine of his son, Heremon. The founder of the family was Fergus Kerbeoil,
son of Conal Crinthine, ancestor of the southern Ny Nials and son ̂ |LI^ialI
and the nine hostages who was King of Ireland, A.D. 379* Tbe ancie-. ,ame
was Lochluin and signifies having spears. The heads of the sept were styled
by the Princes of Aileach, and their possessions were located in the present
County Donegal.
Ancient Tirowen (Tyrone) was peopled by the race of Owen, son of Nial and
the nine hostages, and on the introduction of surnames they took the name
of O'Neill (from their ancestor Niall Glundubh, the 170th monarch of Ireland)
and some of them took the name of McLaughlin and O'Laughlin from Lochlin,
one of the Kings of Aileach. Some of the McLaughlins during the eleventh
and twelfth centuries were Princes of Tirowen and others of them were monarchs
of Ireland.
One branch, the O'Laughlins, was founded by Fiacha Araidhe, King of Ulster,
in the third century. Their chiefs were styled "Lords of Creigh" and the
possessions of the sept were located in the present Counties of.Clare, Galway
and Donegal.
* Above supplied by Mrs. Gertrude McLaughlin who obtained the information
- from the Columban Fathers.
